SP.P: Because I think they are very fit for such an atheistical Wretch as you to read.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: You are very Civil.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: You know you deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Come, let me see them however.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Let me look in your Face all the While then.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: No you shan't.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Then you shan't see them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Well, let it alone then.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Come give me your Hand, you shall see them, if you will promise to read them over three Times.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: There's my Hand, I'll read them out to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I'll hold your Hand all the While, because I'll be sure of your Performance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: I'll warrant you I'llHe reads. read them.

Q.L: But if it should fall out, as who can tell?
That there MAY BE a God, a Heaven and He held him by the Hand till that Word, and then lt it go: pressing gently one of his Fingers. Hell:
Had I not best consider well, for fear
'T shou'd be too late when my Mistakes appear.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Well, what do you say to them?

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: I'll tell you my Thoughts farther by and by, but first tell me what did you press my Hand for when you let it go.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Did you feel no Motion within you, when you read those Words, There may be a God.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What Motion? What do you talk of?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Come do not deny it, for I am a Witness against you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Witness, for what? I have kill'd no Body, I have robb'd no Body; if you would turn Informer, I value not your Evidence.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: No, no, I shall not turn Informer of that Kind, but I am a Witness in your Maker's Behalf.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What can you Witness?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I'll tell you what I can Witness, I can te∣tify, that your own Conscience is against you, in your impious denying the Existence of that God that gave you Life; you could not conceal it, I tell you I felt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: How do you pretend to know, what my Conscience dictates to me, or what the Result of secret Reflections may be in the Mind? You may be mistaken, have a Care; you know you are not to ear false Witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: It's in vain to struggle with it, 'tis not to to be conceal'd, you betray'd yourself, I tell you,

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: How betray'd myself? you are mighty dark in your Expressions.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Did I not tell you, I would look in your Face all the While your read? Did I not see into the Distraction of your Soul? Did you not turn pale at the very Words, when your Tongue said, There may be a God? Was there not a visible Horror in your Countenance, when you read the Word HEAVEN? A Horror, which signified a Sense of your having no Share in it, or Hope about it? And did I not feel a Trembling in your very Joints, as I held you by the Hand, when you read the Word HELL?

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: And was that it you held me by the Hand for?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Indeed it was; I was persuaded I should find it; for I could never believe, but an Atheist had always a Hell within him, even while he brav'd it out against a Hall without him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: You speak enough to fright one; how can you say so positively a Thing, which you cannot be sure of?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Never add Sin to Sin, 'tis in vain to deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Well, well, its none ofHe is a little Angry. your Business; who made you my Father Confessor?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Nay do not be angry with your Friend, and though you are, do but take the Hint, and be as Angry as you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What Hint, what is it you aim at? your Hints are all so general, I can make nothing of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I aim at nothing but your eternal Felicity, I thought those Lines very apposite to your Case, and was wishing you had them, before I happen'd to see you; I thought, that such a Reflection in the Case of Atheism, so natural, so plain, espe∣cially blessed from him, whose secret Voice can effectually reach the Mind, might be some Means to open your Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Open mine Eyes! to what?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: To something that I am persuaded you see already in Part, though I find you struggle hard against your own Convictions.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What is this something you speak of?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I Mean in a few Words, what the Lines you have read mean, viz. That perhaps there may be a God a Heaven, and Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: I don't knowHe observes Tears stands in his Eyes. but there may.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Will, I see it begins to touch you, if you are uncertain, that is a Step to Conviction; and the rest of the Words you have read, are a most natural Inference in your Case.

Q.P: 'T shou'd be too late when your Mistakes appear.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What would you have me consider?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I am not able to enter into that Part now; the first Thing is to persuade you to look in; listen to the Voice of Conscience, I am satisfied you stand convicted at that Bar, you cannot plead Not guilty there.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Convicted of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Of having acted contrary to the Light of Nature, of Reason, and indeed of common Sense; most impously denied the God whose Air you breath in, whose Earth you tread on, whose Food you eat, whose Cloaths you wear, who is your Life, and will be your Judge

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: I do not absolutely deny; I tell you, I don't know, but there may be a God.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Don't you know but there may! O SIR, I beseech you repent; for certainly THERE IS A GOD, depend upon it, I SAY SO.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: YouHe starts and locks surpriz'd. Fright me.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Indeed I think it may well Fright you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: But you fright me upon a quite differing Account from what you imagine; I am indeed ve∣ry much surpris'd, and so would you too if you knew the Circumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: What Circumstance?

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Pray did you hear those Words spoken any where to Day before you spoke them.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: No, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Was you at Mr.—'s Chamber about half an Hour ago?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I have not been there this Month past, I have given over visiting him, and all such as he is, long ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Have you seen him to Day, or when did you last see him, did he speak those Words to you, or you to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P:
I have not seen him, since I saw him with you about fourteen Days ago, when your Discourse (even both of you) was so Blasphemous and so Atheistical, as made my very Heart tremble, and
I resolv'd never to come into Company with ei∣ther of you again, and it was that very Discourse, that made me think of you when I found those Lines in this Book; I should think it an evident Discovery of God, and what I might hope should best forward your Conviction, if his Providence should have sent you to this Door at that Minute, to receive the Hint on this Occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: There is something more than common, in every Thing that has happened to me to Day!

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: If you would explain yourself a little, I might say more; but you know very well, I can∣not make the least guess at what you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Ask me no more Questions, there must be AHe looks wildly and amaz'd. GOD or A DEVIL in Being.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Dear Friend, there are both, depend upon it, but I beseech you compose your Mind, and do not receive the Conviction with Horror, but with Comfort and Hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: One or other of them has been concern'd in what has happen'd to me to Day; it has been a strange Day with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: If it relates only to these Things, perhaps it may be of Use to you to communicate the Par∣ticulars, at least it may give some vent to the Op∣pression of Thought, which you seem to be under, you cannot open your Mind to One, that has more earnest Desires to do you Good, tho' per∣haps not sufficiently furnish'd to advise you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P:
I must tell it orHere he gave him the whole Story of his going to his Friend's Chamber, in order to take him with him to the wicked Club they had kept, and how he had met him at the Door, and said the same Words to him, that the Student had repeated, and when he had done, says he to his Friend; Burst;
and who now do you think must dictate the same Words to him, and afterwards to you, to say to me on the same Occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Who do I think! Nay, who do you think?

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Who! The Devil, if there is a Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Why, do you think theHe stands Stock-still, and says not a Word, which the other perceiving, goes on. Devil preaches Repentance!

DIV1.P: Pray think seriously, for I see it does a little touch your Reason; is it likely the Devil should bid ei∣ther of us, or both of us, intreat you to repent? Is it the Devil think you, that would pronounce the Certainty of the great Truth I speak of? Is it his Business to convince you that there is a God?

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: That's very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: One Thing however, I'll say in Satan's Behalf; and that is, that he never came up to your height of Sinning. The Devil has frequently set up himself, and persuaded poor deluded People to worship him as a God; but to do him Justice, he never had the Impudence to deny the Being of a God; that's a Sin purely Human, and even among Men very Modern too, the Invention of witty Men, as they call themselves; a Way they have late∣ly found out to cherish superlative Wickedness, and flatter themselves, that they shall have no Au∣dit of their Accompts in a Future State; of whom it may indeed be said in that Particular, they have out-sinn'd the Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Indeed I think we have.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I wish you would consider a little farther of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What can Men consider that have gone that Length?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Yes, yes, remember what St. Peter said to Simon the Sorcerer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Read Acts viii. 22. Repent therefore of this thy Wickedness, and pray God, if perhaps the thought of thine Heart may be forgiven thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: No, No, the last of your Verses is against me there most directly.

DIV1.P: Its all TOO LATE now my Mistakes appear.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: No, no, Remember what you said, that it must be a God or a Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What is that to the Purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Why you seem'd satisfied, that it could not be from the Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: But what the better am I for that, if the other is my Enemy?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Much the better if it was from God, if the Words you heard were from God, and that two un∣concerted Persons so eminently concurr'd in speak∣ing to you, you cannot believe God would bid you REPENT, if it was too late, or if he were your irreconcileable Enemy; on the contrary, if you believe it to be the Voice of his Providence, you ought to listen to and obey it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: You have a strange Power of Persuasion, there's no resisting your Argument.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: It is not in me to persuade, but Heaven may make use of me to convince.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: To convince is to persuade, I am convinc'd that I have been a dreadful Wretch.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I am persuaded you were convinc'd of that before.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: I cannot deny but my Heart always struck me, a kind of chill Horror ran through my Veins, when I have utter'd the blasphemous Opi∣nions that I have been drawn into, my very Blood stagnated at the Thought of it, and I look back on it with Astonishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I tell you, I felt a Tremor even in your Flesh, when you read the Word, a God, a Hea∣ven, a Hell.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: I confess to you my very Heart sunk with∣in me at the Words who can tell; my Soul answer'd that I could tell myself, that it both is, and must be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Conscience is a faithful and never-failing Evidence in his Maker's Behalf.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: It is a very terrible Evidence against me, and where will it End?

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I hope it will End where it began, I mean in a heavenly Call to you to Repentance.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: That is not always the Consequence of Conviction.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: You must therefore distinguish again of what proceeds from Heaven, what from Hell, the Voice of God, and the Voice of the Devil; the first calls upon you to repent, the last prompts you to despair.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Despair seems to be the natural Conse∣quence of denying God; for it shuts out the Power that can alone restore the Mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: The greater is that Love which refuses to be shut out, that sends such a heavenly Summons to you to repent, and in so eminent a Manner; it is not your having been an Enemy, a Blasphemer, a Denyer of God; Peter denied Christ three Times, nay, the third Time he even abjur'd him, and yet mark the Words, The Lord look'd on him, and immediately he repented.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: My Case is worse than Peter's.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: And yet you see you are call'd on to repent.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: I think you are call'd to make me repent, there's no answering you.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Amen; may I have the Blessing of being an Instrument to so good a Work, there seems to be something extraordinary in it all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: It's All a Surprise to me, how came I hi∣thr!

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Nay, how came I hither! how came this Book here! who writ the Lines in the Frontis∣piece ! how came I to read them! 'tis all a Dream to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: How came you to think of me upon the reading them! and how came I here just at the He lifts up his Hands and cries out, There is a God, certainly there is, I am con∣vinc'd of it, it must be so. Moment, and out of my Way too!

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Nothing more certain; nor is there any Doubt but all these Things are of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: But there are yet greater Things behind, I wish you would go with me to my Friend Mr.—'s Chamber, I am persuaded some∣thing yet more extraordinary must have befallen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: With all my Heart.They both go to the first Gentleman's Cham∣ber, and found him at Home very much out of Order, but willing enough to dis∣course with them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Well, Friend of mine, I hope you are bet∣ter dispos'd to your Friends than when I saw you last.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Truly when I saw you last, I was disposed of by the Devil, and so I doubt was you; I hope I shall never come into that horrid Place again.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: What horrid Place?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: You know where I mean, I tremble at the very Thoughts of the Place, and much more of the Company; I wish I could prevail upon you to come no more among them too; I assure you if I know myself, and if God would assist me to do it, I would much rather go to a Stake to be burnt.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: I rejoice in such an Alteration, Sir, upon you, I hope our Friend here is of the same Mind, long may it continue in you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Well, pray tell us something of the Occa∣sion of this happy Alteration; for it will seem still more strange, how you came to be instrumental to my Change, if I know nothing of the Means that brought about your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Mine! I assure you, it was all from Hea∣ven: Not the Light that shone about St. Paul, was more immediately from Heaven, than the Stroke that touch'd my Soul; it is true, I had no Voice without, but a Voice has spoken (I hope) effe∣ctually to my Understanding, I had Voice enough to tell me, how I was n the Hands of that Power, that Majesty, that GOD, whom I had wickedly, and with a Hardness not to be expressed, disown'd and deny'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Stud.
SP.P: Pray Sir, if you care to have it known, give us some Account of the Particulars of this wonderful Thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Sir, I shall do itHere he gives an Account of the Surprise he was in by the Lightning, how he was stopt in his Way to his wicked Com∣pany, and went back to his Chamber. freely, I think I ought not to conceal it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Well, now I will no more wonder at the Salutation you gave me, when I came to call you, but thank you for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: What Salutation?

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Why, when I was at your Chamber about two Hours ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: You at my Chamber!

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Nay, you need not conceal it, for I have told our Friend here all the Story.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: I know nothing of what you talk of, much less what you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Nay, what need you go about to conceal it? I tell you I do not take it ill, I hope I may have Reason to be thankful for what you said to me, and look upon it as spoken from Heaven; for I assure you, it has been an Introduction to that Light in my Thoughts, which I hope shall never be extinguish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Dear Friend, as I believe you are serious, so I hope you believe I am so; I profess I know nothing of all you talk about.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Why, was I not at your Door this After∣noon, a little after the great Shower of Rain?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Why, did not I knock at your Chamber-Door, and you come to the Door yourself and speak to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Not to Day, I am very sure of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Am I awake! are you Mr.—am I sure we are all alive, and know what we are say∣ing, and to who?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: I beseech you unriddle yourself, for I am surprised.

SP.SPEAKER: Ath.
SP.P: Why, about three a Clock this Afternoon, I came to this Chamber-Door; I knock'd; you came and open'd the Door; I began to speak, you interrupted me, and—

DIV1.Q: Here he repeats the Passage a large, and his own Thoughts, and Resent∣ment as before.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Depend upon it, 'twas some Voice from Heaven, it was nothing of mine; I have not been at the Door since two of the Clock, when I came first in, but have been on the Bed or in my Study ever since, wholly taken up with my own Thoughts, and very much indispos'd.

DIV1.Q: The young Man turns Pale, and falls into a Swound.
DIV1.P: There was a great deal more belonging to this Story, but 'tis too long for the present Purpose, I have related this Part on several Accounts, and it hits the Purpose I am upon many Ways.

1. Here is a visible Evidence of God, and of his Being and Nature fix'd so in the Mind, that not the most hardn'd Atheist can deny it, Nature recoils at every Endeavour to sup∣press it, and the very Pulsation of his Blood shall discover and acknowledge it.

2. Yet even in this, we see how the Power of Imagination may be work'd up, by the se∣cret Agency of an unknown Hand, how ma∣ny Things concurr'd to make this Man be∣lieve he had seen an Apparition, and heard a Voice, and yet there was nothing in it but the Voice of a Man unseen and mistaken; the young Man was so surprised at his Friends declaring that he knew nothing of his coming there, that he concluded it had been all a Vision or Apparition that opened the Door, and that it was a Voice that had spoken to him, of what Kind he knew not; and the Reflection upon this surprised him so much as threw him into a Swound, and yet here was neither Vision or Voice, but that of an ordinary Person, and one who meant well, and said well.

It is not to be doubted, but that many an Ap∣parition related with a great deal of Certainty in the World, and of which good Ends have fol∣low'd, has been no more than such a serious Mi∣stake as this.

But before I leave it, let me observe, that this should not at all hinder us from making a very good Use of such Things; for many a Voice may be directed from Heaven, that is not immediately spoken from thence; as when the Children cried Hosannah to our Saviour, they fulfilled the Scrip∣ture, which said out of the Mouths of Babes and Sucklings thou hast ordain'd Praise; so doubtless he that made all Things and created all Things; may appoint Instruction to be given by fortuitous Accidents, and may direct concurring Circum∣stances to touch and affect the Mind as much, and as effectually, as if they had been immediate and miraculous.

Thus was the two Persons happening to say the same Words to the Atheist, the strange reading of those Lines, when the Person came into the Book∣seller's Shop, the incident of his running into the Shop for Shelter, and many the like Things of the same Nature, and order'd in the same Manner as the Cock crowing when Peter denied Christ, which though wonderfully concurrent with what his blessed Master had foretold, yet was no extraor∣dinary Thing in a Cock, who naturally Crows at such a Time of the Morning.

In a Word, all these Things serve to convince us of a great Super-intendency of Divine Provi∣dence in the minutest Affairs of this World, of a manifest Existence of the invisible World, of the Reality of Spirits, and of the Intelligence between us and them. I hope I have said nothing of it to mis-guide any Body, or to assist them to delude themselves, having spoken of it with the utmost Seriousness in my Design, and with a sincere Desire for a General Good.
